Award.AwardTitle: Rapid Landscape Change in Garwood Valley: Monitoring Buried Glacier Melt and Exploring Pewe's Lost Lake
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
An expansive stratigraphic column has recently become exposed in Garwood Valley by river erosion into a buried ice mass. This LGM-aged ice is a remnant of the Ross Ice Sheet that filled Garwood Valley ~10-20 ky ago, damming a paleo-lake that has recently been uncovered. The buried ice mass is preserved beneath a cap of paleo-lake deposits, glacial drift, and permafrost landforms. The superimposed deposits provide a meters-thick record of landscape changes that can be well dated due to the presence of several fossil algal mat and carbonate horizons. The PIs propose to quantify paleo- and modern rates of climate-driven landscape change in Garwood Valley. The PIs also propose to quantify the current rate of buried ice removal from Garwood Valley to generate a geomorphological baseline for documenting landscape change associated with future ice removal. Measurements and modeling of the current ablation of buried ice will quantify present landscape changes in the MDV that are being caused by disequilibrium between climate and the landscape. This proposal will address ambiguity over the timing and extent of valley filling in the southern MDV by LGM ice sheets, and the rates and processes of ice sheet drainage from the valleys.

Broader impacts:
This project will provide Antarctic field research opportunities for undergraduate students and graduate students. The dramatic melting occurring in Garwood Valley will serve as a vivid example of climate-driven landscape change in Antarctica will be shared with K-12 students and the public at large through live, in-the-field teleconferences mediated by a public school teacher and expert in science outreach. The data that the project will generate will be synthesized into a 3D tour of the field site with expert commentary, suitable for museum display.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to determine how the cold desert landscape in Garwood Valley, Antarctica, is changing in response to changing climate conditions. Specifically, the project aimed to reconstruct the geological and glacial history of the valley over the past ~20 thousand years to provide context for understanding how deposits that formed during the last ice age are responding to change in the valley climate. This goal is important—Garwood Valley’s buried ice landforms grew when the Ross Sea Ice Sheet flooded into the valley, damming an ice-age era lake. The collapse of that ancient ice sheet mirrors the mechanisms causing modern ice sheets to thin and collapse, providing a model for understanding how quickly ice sheets can change in response to climate forcing.

In the field, the research focused on 1) measuring the rate at which buried ice in the valley is melting away, 2) measuring the local climate processes that are causing the melt, and 3) characterizing and dating the sediments that formed in the Garwood Valley paleolake before these ice-cemented deposits all melt away (in one place, more than 8,000 cubic meters of paleolake sediments that could have been used to reconstruct past conditions in the valley have melted and flowed away during the course of the project—that’s about 80 tractor trailer’s worth of geological records turned into mud!). 

We used radiocarbon dating and a new technique called Optically Stimulated Luminescence dating to determine when sand and gravel were deposited in the Garwood paleolake. When the sediments first showed up tells us when the ice sheet thickened to dam the lake. The hypothesis was that the end of the lake marked the collapse of the ice sheet in the Ross Sea. Our results show that the lake was dammed about 24 thousand years ago (in line with other studies), but that the lake persisted until nearly 3.5 thousand years ago (much more recently than most other workers thought). We interpreted this surprising result to mean that Garwood Valley is a unique location where the buried ice (that is still present in the valley) acted as a persistent dam, keeping the ancient lake around longer than in areas where the ice sheet itself impounded a lake.

We measured the rate of ice loss in Garwood Valley using a laser scanner. By measuring the topography of a portion of the valley twice a year, the team was able to calculate how much the ground was subsiding due to ice melting and due to blocks of ice and frozen soil breaking off and falling into the Garwood River (together, a processes called thermokarst). By dating when the sediment above the ice was emplaced and by measuring how much material had been removed to carve the Garwood River valley, we found that the average rate of erosion in Garwood Valley has been about 500 cubic meters per year for the last 4 thousand years. From 2001 to 2010, that rate increased to 5,400 cubic meters per year, reaching as high as 6,200 cubic meters per year in 2013. That erosion rate is much higher than the long-term average. By measuring climate conditions at the base of the melting ice exposure, we were able to show that the increase in melting rate over the past several years has been do to local increases in the amount of shortwave sunlight reaching the ground, while the long term trend towards higher melt volumes is consistent with deepening ground thaw associated with regional warming. We found that thermokarst erosion, which has long been thought to be shaping Arctic landscapes, is now a major, and increasingly important geological process in Antarctica.
